livres.resume_court: How to benefit from chaos and uncertainty. Things that gain from disorder.
livres.resume_long: Nassim Nicholas Taleb offers a revolutionary lesson: not only to survive the catastrophes of our time - the Black Swans that hit a person, a culture, or a civilization - but to turn them into benefits. Just as the human body strengthens under stress and effort, and popular movements grow when repressed, living things in general develop better when exposed to disorder, volatility, or anything that disrupts them. This ability not only to profit from chaos but to need it to become better is antifragility, like the Lernaean Hydra whose heads multiplied when cut off.

livres.resume_court: The power of the unpredictable. Understanding rare, high-impact events.
livres.resume_long: The Black Swan reveals the nature of Black Swans - highly improbable, random events that punctuate our lives: they have massive impact, are almost impossible to predict, and yet after the fact we always try to find a rational explanation. According to Taleb's Black Swan theory, a Black Swan is an unpredictable event with a low probability of occurring that, if it occurs, has consequences of exceptional magnitude. They are totally unexpected and their impact is huge, but our brains will find logical reasons to explain them after the fact.

The book is a deep exploration of justice, courage, and true expertise.

livres.resume_long: Sapiens offers an overview of human history and evolution from the late Pleistocene to the 21st century. The main argument is that Homo sapiens became the dominant species because it is the only animal capable of cooperating efficiently with large numbers of others. Yuval Noah Harari divides human evolution into four phases: cognitive revolution, agricultural revolution, unification of humankind, and industrial revolution. He also explains the emergence of concepts such as religion, nation, and human rights.
